channel.title: The Hon. Artur Davis
channel.description: The Hon. Artur Davis Former U.S. Representative ­ Alabama (Remarks as Prepared for Delivery)

item.title: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Some of you may know, the last time I spoke at a convention, it turned out I was in the wrong place.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: So, Tampa, my fellow Republicans, thank you for welcoming me where I belong.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: We have a country to turn around. This week you will nominate the most experienced executive to seek the presidency in 60 years in Mitt Romney.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: He has no illusions about what makes America great, and he doesn't confuse the presidency with celebrity, or loftiness with leadership.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: What a difference four years makes.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: The Democrats' ads convince me that Governor Romney can't sing, but his record convinces me he knows how to lead, and I think you know which skill we need more.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Now, America is a land of second chances, and I gather you have room for the estimated 6 million of us who know we got it wrong in 2008 and who want to fix it.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Maybe we should have known that night in Denver that things that begin with plywood Greek columns and artificial smoke typically don't end well.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Maybe the Hollywood stars and the glamour blinded us a little: you thought it was the glare, some of us thought it was a halo.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: But in all seriousness, do you know why so many of us believed? We led with our hearts and our dreams that we could be more inclusive than America had ever been, and no candidate had ever spoken so beautifully. But dreams meet daybreak: the jobless know what I mean, so do the families who wonder how this Administration could wreck a recovery for three years and counting.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: So many of those high-flown words have faded.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Remember the President saying of negative politics and untrue ads, "not this time?"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Who knew "not this time" just meant "not unless the economy is still stuck and we can't run on our record?"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Remember, too, when he said, "this was the moment when the rise of the oceans began to slow and our planet began to heal?"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Who knew the plain English version of it was, "middle America, get ready to shell out 60 bucks to fill up your car?"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: And in terms of their crown jewel legislative achievement: who knew that when asked, "will government impose a new federal mandate requiring middle class Americans to buy health insurance whether they can afford it or not?"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: The answer would be "Yes we can!"
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: So, this time, in the name of 23 million of our children and parents and brothers and sisters who are officially unemployed, underemployed, or who have stopped looking for work, let's put the poetry aside, let's suspend the hype, let's come down to earth and start creating jobs again.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: This time, instead of moving oceans and healing planets, let's get our bills in order and pay down the debt so we control our own future.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: And of course, we know that opportunity lies outside the reach of some of our people.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: We don't need flowery words about inequality to tell us that, and we don't need a party that has led while poverty and hunger rose to record levels to give us lectures about suffering.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Ladies and gentlemen, there are Americans who are listening to this speech tonight who haven't always been with you, and I want you to let me talk -- just to them ­ for a moment.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: I know how loaded up our politics is with anger and animosity, but I have to believe we can still make a case over the raised voices.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: There are Americans who voted for the president, but who are searching right now, because they know that their votes didn't build the country they wanted.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: To those Democrats and independents whose minds are open to argument: listen closely to the Democratic Party that will gather in Charlotte and ask yourself if you ever hear your voice in the clamor. Ask yourself if these Democrats still speak for you.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: When they say we have a duty to grow government even when we can't afford it, does it sound like compassion to you -- or recklessness?
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: When you hear the party that glorified Occupy Wall Street blast success; when you hear them minimize the genius of the men and women who make jobs out of nothing, is that what you teach your children about work?
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: When they tell you America is this unequal place where the powerful trample on the powerless, does that sound like the country your children or your spouse risked their lives for in Iraq or Afghanistan?
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Do you even recognize the America they are talking about? And what can we say about a house that doesn't honor the pictures on its walls?
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: John F. Kennedy asked us what we could do for America. This Democratic Party asks what can government give you. Don't worry about paying the bill, it's on your kids and grandkids.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Bill Clinton took on his base and made welfare a thing you had to work for; this current crowd guts the welfare work requirement in the dead of night.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: Bill Clinton, Jack Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson reached out across the aisle and said meet me in the middle; but their party rammed through a healthcare bill that took over one-sixth of our economy, without accepting a single Republican idea, without winning a single vote in either house from a party whose constituents make up about 50 percent of the country.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: You know, the Democrats used to have a night when they presented a film of their presidential legends: if they do it in Charlotte, the theme song should be this year's hit, "Somebody That I Used to Know."
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: My fellow Americans, when great athletes falter, their coaches sometimes whisper to them "remember who you are." It's a call to their greatness at a moment when their bodies and spirit are too sapped to remember their strength.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: This sweet, blessed, God-inspired place called America is a champion that has absorbed some blows.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: But while we bend, we don't break.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: This is no dark hour; this is the dawn before we remember who we are.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: May it be said of this time in our history: 2008 to 2011: lesson learned.
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis

item.title: 2012: mistake corrected. God bless you, God bless America. Thank you
item.author: The Hon. Artur Davis
